if you have any questions just ask any of the good folks with you asked me or the staff here in the room so with that
welcome to our first panel of the day this is the open government data panel I
am your host and your moderator Jon Stevenson I am part of the AWS global
public policy team here and someone who has both benefited and worked towards
open data but despite my very minor role I've been very big fans of the panelists
we have here today because they've been driving a lot of the open data efforts both from a policy and a business
perspective really all over the world so what we'd like to do today is to have
them share some of their perspectives their thoughts and where do they see open data going in the in the aftermath
of the open data government Act here in the United States and also efforts internationally in places like Canada
I'm here to be the moderator facilitator to get the conversation going at the end we'll have time for some
questions from the audience so I hope you'll have some good things you want to ask our panel because we really have a
great deep pool of talent and knowledge here about open data our panelists are
Mona Siddiqui who is the chief data officer for the US Department of Health
and Human Services we're also joined by dan castro vice-president of the information Tecna
and innovation Foundation Tom Lee who is the director of policy of MapBox
and last but certainly not least Janie Boyd who is the director of open government for the Treasury Board of
Canada so let's dive right in to our panel questions to start with you and
why is important to your agency's mission yeah I think huge culture shift
for us in the last ten years during the last administration I would say we were really the leaders in the federal space
and making data available for researchers and entrepreneurs and released about 2000 data sets for public
use where we really have been looking now is not only but also how are we
helping facilitate that data being used by the 29 different units within HHS
because oftentimes the challenges that exist for people to have access to our
data on the outside are the same challenges that we face internally as a
as a large organization and getting access inside and so that has been sort
of the dual focus for the work that we're doing excellent Dan I'm certainly
very familiar with iti F and have read your incredible thoughtful work but for the benefit of our audience tell us a
little bit about iti F what you do on open data and why it's important to your work yeah so thank you and thanks for
the opportunity to be here so I'm with an organization called the information technology and innovation foundation I
run our for data innovation so we're a think-tank we're focused on the intersection of Technology data and public policy our mission is really to
help policymakers understand how data is a new kind of lever in government that
they can use to help achieve better outcomes whether it's in health care or education or or any other public goal
that they have and so part of the way that you can use data is is through open data through making more data available
and accessible through improving data quality through thinking about how data is collected and can be shared with
different partners under different mechanisms and if you go back it was you
know when Obama of course came into the office as president that was you know right right at the very beginning there
was an open government directive that said you know openness is gonna be a key part of how government goes forward and
data is gonna be a part of that and you know they move forward and they started doing a number of open data projects and
one of our recommendations at the time was that you know this needs to be something that transcends more than one
presidency there should be something that is just part of what the federal government does and we were starting to see states and local governments doing
this and so we worked with some members of Congress to put together the open government data act which you know
qualified this role and you know it was just this past January where the law went into effect and now you know we
have the big challenge ahead of us of how do we take this this really important law and implement it and make
sure that it is the purpose we want to see in terms of much more openness and data in the future thank you so Tom
mapbox I've certainly been made familiar with your company through my work and
learning how to code for the benefit of our audience tell us a little about mapbox and how you use open data and why
it's important to your company sure well we're a map and location services company as you might have guessed the mapping parts probably
obvious we provide really beautiful customizable maps to clients like snapchat tik-tok visualization folks
like tableau or you know whether absolute the Weather Channel the location services are things like
finding directions to a point on that map or searching for an address or a point of interest and open data
particularly from government sources this is a key part of how we do business we stitched together dozens and dozens of data sources to power those maps and
services some of or community projects like OpenStreetMap or wiki data is some are proprietary some we make ourselves out of data we
collect but government has a fundamental role to play in the creation of spatial data for one thing it's really expensive
and complicated fly satellites those turn out to be important government tends to be involved there and for another there are types of data that are
crucial to our business that government is the source of truth for so the address number on a house they get to
make that up the boundaries where a district or county begins and ends like
that is canonically defined by governments so they're always part of this flow and ensuring that that data is
accessible and useful as basic infrastructure for everyone in the industry and and everyone out there needs to use maps in the course of their
daily lives that's that's a crucial part of any open data policy Jamie we've
talked and we started this panel talking about the United States open government data Act but that's certainly not the
only government in the world that's really been leading the way and really been driving forward open government
open data so talk to us a little bit about what's happening at Treasury Board of Canada and just Canada's open
government efforts it is so exciting to see a room full of people who want to
talk about open data so thank you for coming out to join us for that it's often smaller rooms people are a little
bit less excited so it's particularly reassuring to me to know that there's at least enthusiasm for a future based on
open data so I work at the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat it's a central agency that essentially
coordinates the federal family in Canada when it comes to ITIM and in my case
open data we went on a website opened Canada dossier we host about 80,000 data
sets from 66 federal departments and agencies we also have all the proactive disclosure content around contracting
hospitality position reclassification for 115 federal departments and agencies
essentially what we're trying to do with this portal with open Canada dossier is maximize the release of high quality
content that's going to allow Canadians Canadian businesses innovators around
the world to make use of what we can put really rich and higher quality content we've gone through quite an evolution in
the a couple of years we started it off in the sort of late 2000s I'm just saying
let's let's spit out all the data that we can so in Canada we have a huge country obviously we've invested quite
heavily in our satellite systems we have great geospatial data it was like fantastic we'll take that and we'll open
it up allow people to do what they will with with this open data so we started off with way more data than we have now
and we've gone through a bit of an evolution we created our 2014 directive on open government that was still
talking about accelerating and maximizing the release of open data and over time we realized that it was more
important to focus on quality predictability and really availability of the things that people wanted so over
time we've consolidated a lot of our data sets we've built a lot of capacity within the federal family so that folks
can better understand what innovator is like our friends at box or anywhere else in the ecosystem what is it that they're
going to use to really advance service delivery to citizens the kinds of
objectives that we're embracing when we push on open data are things like transparency you should know what your
government is up to your tax payer you should you should have that awareness accountability so you should know what
kind of decisions I'm making as a federal official when it comes to government procurement you should be able to easily understand that sort of
thing and that's exactly why we lower the threshold for a proactive disclosure of grants and contributions to $1.00 so
you can see all federal grants and contributions in Canada now and citizen participation so it isn't just about hey
look I've opened up 80,000 data sets it's all right what are we gonna do on the basis of that so we developed
national action plans every two years with with Canadians with citizens and for the most recent one that we did we
had 10,000 Canadians that helped us develop that plan so we're really trying to build out that sort of that resilience and the feedback loops on the
basis of the content that we're making available Thank You Jane Thank You Jaime and I echo your comments that's
wonderful to see such a large crowd here to talk about open data perhaps they thought we were going to talk about
basketball
[Laughter] moving on so we've talked a little bit
about you know the government's role in promoting open data open data policies at Government of Canada the United
States government but I'm curious for the panel and this is an open question for anybody
what's our private sector role you know here at AWS you know we make a lot of data available free and open to the
public using our storage and and other products Tom Matt box is an open-source tool but
I'm curious for the panel like what role can the private sector play in in encouraging use of open data making it
more valuable to government agencies to other citizens what do you see as some
of the ways they can do that anybody on the panel I guess it's it's maybe most
straightforward to use an example like map so I'll start since this should be relatively easy but like if you go to
the US Census website or maybe better their FTP sites since these are some
creaky systems you will find a ton of geospatial data and I'm sure there many people in the audience who could make
use of it but it is probably not in the final form you would want to get it in right you would have to download it over the course of days and transform it into
something that would actually serve your purposes and probably combine it with other datasets as well so there's
there's obviously a role for people to integrate this data and create compelling user experiences that you
know serves particular market needs it's not before map box I was at a nonprofit
called the sunlight foundation and this was often division that we talked about it should government be a data retailer
or a wholesaler and we came down on the latter half right the thought was that government is not really set up to
figure out all the different use cases in the market that exists or could exist what they need to do is provide the
infrastructure that can then be developed by businesses that try new things the fail that succeed and try to
build a sort of sustainable set of underlying systems just like the roads outside or the pipes under our feet
that power this important part of the economy and I guess the other part that's incumbent on the private sector
beyond have doing their jobs and trying to build these businesses is to be part of this conversation about where do we
draw the line on socializing these costs right it's at some point the end users should be paying for the creation and
maintenance this data but it's hard to figure out exactly where that lies because there's also a gigantic amount of stuff where it
makes sense to share these costs it's it's utility that everybody needs so figuring out that balance is a key part
and you know being part of the conversation is incumbent on us - thank you Tom others thoughts on that what role the
private sector can play yeah I'll just say you know I think one of the challenges the government has sometimes
is basically hearing out how it can manage all the stay that has and get it
out there in a way that's useful one of the I think most interesting projects I've seen over the last couple years
came about through a partnership that the Department of Commerce specifically NOAA the National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration did where they had it was something like on the order of 19 terabytes of data a day they
were being produced from some of their geospatial satellites and monitoring and
they said this was more data than they could with their existing infrastructure make available publicly and so what they
did is they said we'll see if we can partner with the private sector to do something interesting here and so they
had a what was a no-cost contract so it didn't cost the government anything where they said you know open to any
partners in the in the private sector that want to partner with us if you make a certain amount of data that we have here publicly available with these you
know conditions so no cost to the public then then you can do you can add any
other value-added services you want on top of that and we saw a number of partners step up and do that I believe the Amazon was one of those partners and
to me that's the kind of partnerships that German deliver tremendous value because you had data that was previously
inaccessible now available to the public you had the government able to do more without expending any taxpayer dollars
and then you had the private sector being able to also monetize this data in
ways that they wouldn't have been able to do either and so it was kind of a win on all sides and so I think as we as we
start moving forward in this area there's questions about how can we have more of these really innovative partnerships where we think about you
know what's next beyond just government putting data on on data portals and we think about this kind of long tail of
you know the super large data sets the data sets that maybe are sensitive and needs to be released in certain more
private context and figure out how we get more data out there because that's how we more value can add something and I guess
I'll speak from my particular perspective of being at a health care agency obviously the health care sector
is highly regulated the data that we have is also incredibly highly regulated
and I think that we need to have an engage in a long-term proactive conversation around the norms and the
rules around privacy and the granularity of the data that we're all comfortable with releasing and you know I don't
think anybody now really questions which I think they probably did ten years ago questions
about you have open data but how do you get there in a way that that data is actually usable and that we're not just
doing a check the box and you know we make data available but it's not in a way that can really be connected to
other datasets or or linked for purpose
as a really creating value and I don't really see that conversation happening right now in a robust way across the
public and private sector and I think it's no longer sufficient to do a lot of hand waving around open data I think we
have to have a really deep conversation around the limits of what we're
comfortable with sharing whether it's behavioral mental health data and and how do we feel about that as citizens
and as as government or you know it's it's other information that can be
really highly sensitive and so what is that calculus between between value and
individual privacy I'm just curious just by a show of hands
who here is in the public sector and private sector all right so it's a
little bit biased towards the public sector it's helpful context I've been
working in the space for a number of years and I think that the the role of the private sector in maximizing the value and impact of government's opening
up data is unprecedented you know I spent a lot of time talking my face off about digital change and like no digital
change is not gradually happening to us it has happened like we live in a world where sure I'm opening up really high
quality road network data pretty sure who's got better road network data than I do right same goes for labor market
data employment and Social Development Canada has fantastic data pretty sure that we were met to mash it up with
LinkedIn data we would be better off collectively right so you can think of really interesting case studies where
the private sector can not only innovate often better than the private than the public sector with the value of the data
but it can also add to it in really exciting ways now of course there are all sorts of interesting dynamics in
terms of how do you monetize that how do you allow it to sort of build out your business model but you can really easily
think about using data that is in private sector possession to build the ecosystems that are going to be more
powerful and sort of more robust than they would be on your own so I'll give you a very quick example a major car
manufacturer came to us and they said hey we've got this cool new fleet of cards they've got these little sensors and as they're driving along the road if
they bump Filson you know it they'll basically indicate that there's a pothole forming so that's an example of
opening up that data you feed it into the municipality and they can say I've got a I've got a road issue right and
now I'm filling up a pothole before it's turned into a major you know sinkhole we
have cold winters and the roads are terrible in Canada so being able to
identify road network issues early on on the basis of private sector generated open data is going to be way better it's
good for fleet maintenance it's good for the drivers experience but it's also good from a public sector efficiency perspective and that's data that we
simply do not have the capacity to collect or disseminate within the public sector but we've got awesome data with
regards to the materials that are used for the road network yeah you know all that sort of thing so it's sort of a silly little
anecdote but I think it's a telling one in that if you use private-sector generated data you mash it up with public sector you can get some really
exciting scope for collaboration obviously we have to be careful from a privacy and security perspective but it
seems like those are conversations that are well worth having on a collective basis so Bona like to turn back to you
with a two-part question you talked about you know overpass kind of the technical conversations you know we
there's widespread consensus that open data is goods here at stay and HHS I
think has really been at the forefront before others even in the US government driving the open data conversation
forward so how how do you think the open data government act is helping to
achieve the mission of you know extracting value and and what are you you mentioned some of the things you're
hoping to achieve on whether on mental health behavioral health pharmaceuticals
well what are some of the outcomes you're working towards with with open data well first I guess I just want to
make sure we're all on the same page around what that is so how many people are familiar with what it says and it's
not I can okay so maybe I'll just give a couple and you can help and adding to it
but so the foundations for evidence-based policymaking Act actually
now mandates that federal departments have a chief data officer they are mandating it mandates that we
make data open by default unless we can provide a reason otherwise it also asks
federal departments to have evaluation plans and to to map out how that how
those evaluation plans would lead to policies that are evidence-based and so
it's really a transformative I think piece of legislation if we actually and and I'll say this I think
anytime something gets mandated and and and there's a
reporting function build out around it in the federal space it's very easy for it to become a compliance activity and
so my hope is that where we really move towards is not just the letter of the
law but really the vision of the law which is ultimately how do you create a government that is more data-driven and
evidence-based in the way we've foreign policies and how we think about resource allocation and and and so I do think
that the law sort of lays out that roadmap HHS has for the last two years
really been setting I think the foundation for doing this so I think we might be a little bit ahead of the game
where we've taken some time to understand the challenges when it comes to data sharing and those are you know
technical yes because we still put up PDFs on on our websites and call it a
day in many parts those are legal so we have statutory restrictions around how
data can be shared you know we don't have work force capacity to be able to
actually meet the demands of what we're asking people to do so those are some of
the some of the roadblocks and I'm sorry I'm forgetting the second part of your question what are some of the outcomes
mental health suit balls that you're trying to drive towards we think you can yeah it's to look I I think that we
given the enormous scale and scope of the department are probably the stewards
of the largest collection of health care information on the planet and you know I
think perhaps like 1 to 2 percent of it gets used in any meaningful way by folks
who are entrepreneurs and researchers and the potential of connecting
information let's say if you're looking at post-market surveillance data from FDA around the performance of a
particular drug or connecting that information to our CMS information
which is the largest health insurer in the country can pinpoint emerging issues
in a way that we just aren't able to right now so I think the potential is
enormous and and you may be aware of this but I'll bring it up again which is
the opioid hackathon that the Department hosted in 2017 where we made 70 data
sets available for about 250 coders the reason I'm really proud of that is is
not just because we were addressing a specific concern which is the opioid
crisis right now the country around treatment and prevention and his understanding usage but there were three
winners that came out of that of that event and one of those one of those
winners actually was mapping out where you can give back unused prescription
pills because those have been actually
documented to be used by you know kids in households who then got addicted and
and so returning those and having a safe place to return those as a huge thing
that was developed during our event and then it was actually taken up by Google
and Google work with CVS pharmacies and Walgreens and other pharmacies and
collected even more data than what we had so they took our data state data private data and now if you go on Google
Maps this was launched at scale earlier this year so about a year after our event and you can go now and search for
take-back locations across the country so I think the power of data is enormous
clearly we are not going to be within the federal departments the ones who are
coming up with all the innovations and and you know 60% of the people who
participated in our event actually identified themselves coming from a non healthcare background which is phenomenal because you're getting
again people we provided the questions right we said here are some of the things that we really need help with and
private sector come in and help us using our data and so I think that's an example of real public/private
partnership in service of one of the most pressing public health crisis in this country in a meaningful way
and not just a one-and-done sort of an event thank you for that answer
Dan you were probably one of the most instrumental non-government actors in
the open government data act from analysis from providing quality upon the
act I was wondering if you could follow up to Mona's description of what her
agency is doing what the future looks like talk about what you've seen since the Act has been adopted and and where
do you see it heading here in the US and even internationally from from your perspective yeah that was a great
question I mean the good thing is the US has had a strong open data culture in
the federal government for some time and so I think the Act you know kind of
boost what was already happening in a very positive way and ensures that all government agencies are going to be
moving in this direction I think you know you know how to find the need for a chief data officer with every agency is
an important part of this because it's it's saying to the agency it's not just that you need someone who's gonna be you
know making the data open but you need to be thinking about the entire data lifecycle and so you need to be thinking about the collection of it and how it's
being used and you know what kind of partnerships you have around the data and that's the direction we want to move
into this kind of more collaborative space as well as I said it's not government that's gonna be doing
everything with the data it's this kind of new way of thinking about government and its relationship with the public
where it is collaborative and and it's also more transparent and I think that
leads to better outcomes so the the bill passed in January at the same time the
administration was also working on the federal data strategy which since they
had a I think a pretty good sense in the administration that this bill would likely pass the federal data strategy
really Orient's a lot of these agencies innovating with data as well and so I
think that you know is also kind of moving government in this direction and
then you know the kind maybe the third point I make here is that the open government data Act applies to all all
federal data but there's also been some other legislation that's focused on
spending data within government and making that open and standardized as well and so a lot of government agencies
to basically already gone through this exercise of how do we put data in machine readable format how do we make
it available how do we create it so it's more useful around there spending data and now they're thinking about okay that
spending data is a little bit easier because you know it's all basically the same type of data it's amounts and where
it goes now we can apply that same type of thinking though maybe more creatively as we have all these different types of
datasets we're thinking about how to use them and so you know one example that I've seen that's come out you know kind
of open government data act is with the Department of Education and you know they made a commitment they have college
scorecard which you go and you see ratings about different universities and outcomes and they said they wanted to go
further and they want to you know drill down and have more granular data and so just recently it was about two weeks ago
I think they released a new it was the beta data set it included not only data at the university level but also at the
at the major level so the different majors that people pursued a lot of universities and then what their you
know what their student loans look like after a certain period of time what the default rates look like that kind of thing and that's where I think we're
moving into this area where you know you know they recognize yeah this day that was useful but you need to go further if
you want to empower people if we if we see how people are willing to use this data they want to use it to make a decision about what do I do at
university okay it's not just where do I go but what do i do once I'm there and so they're moving in that direction I
think that's what we want and then the question is how do you keep going further in this direction because the the goal has to be to have this kind of
feedback mechanism so the government's hearing what's working what's not working and you know we keep moving to
the space where it's really about how are you empowering the user whether it's and business or consumers dan if we may stay with you
you've done a lot of research and emerging technologies where do you see open data
helping things like AI quantum computing and some of the new the new tech out
there that we're very excited about yeah and that's that's to be right because part of you know we're doing a
lot of research right now assessing where the u.s. stands in terms of artificial intelligence and how this
will affect US economic and national security and you know what we see is
that you know the United States faces a significant challenge from from Europe
in terms of the amount of research R&D that's going on in that space as well as from China in terms of you know the
Chinese strategy and AI as well as Canada who's doing a lot in this space
as well and the question that we have is how do we remain competitive in this space when you look at machine learning
and and you know how you know basically companies and firms are successful in this space it's through of course access
to the large amounts to obstructions and structured data a lot of this is coming from government and so we did have an
executive order from the president that highlighted the need to release federal
models and data that can contribute to machine learning I think that's a perfect you know addition to what is
trying to be achieved with the open government data act to say the government agencies as they're evaluating their datasets and and what
they're released publicly and how to prioritize it that they need to be thinking about its implications on how
this might be used around AI and you know particularly in health care and education I think there's some really
big opportunities I mean there was a great project that came out of Johns Hopkins that used HHS data that was
around predicting predicting diseases so basically based on all the data that they were getting from HHS you know what
likelihood if you have certain symptoms would you have certain diseases just statistically and and that was you know the type of innovations we'd want to see
in this space we want to see it around healthcare cost we want to see this around the upgrade crisis but the only
way to get there is if government's making this data available because oftentimes the private sector does even have access to some of this information
it will never have access to it and so government has to be a stakeholder and getting that out there you can add
something really quickly to that which is you know you connected the open data work to ai and it's not something that people
are doing sort of explicitly but I think we need to make that case and I'm certainly making that at HHS which is
that everyone wants to move to AI right like how do we become AI ready and you
can't have that unless you focus on the non glamorous part which is really
creating the foundation that you need to be able to make it a publicly available and in the right formats and at the
right level and and so I think actually building the building the case for that
work has become easier because of the focus on AI as well
but I think it is it is essential to tie it in the minds of policymakers because it is not explicitly tied Tom we heard

MapBox be successful here sure well so as stan has mentioned the open
government data act really is a codification of existing policy I commend OMB circular n 1313 to everyone
in the audience is good read it's been around since 2013 issued by the Obama administration and kept by this administration which i
think is a testament to what a good idea it is to have open by default machine readable formats to worry about privacy
to maintain enterprise and public inventories of data so this has been the
direction that agencies as indicated have been pushing toward for years now and actually in the geospatial world
this has been sort of the baseline for even longer I mentioned the census FTP server that
predates any government-wide and data policy it's because this data is so crucial for a variety of use cases
that people found ways to open it up relatively early now that's not to say
that this law isn't important for us though it's another really crucial tool in the toolbox because open data is
frankly continuously under assault some of the work that we did on the advocacy side in last year is focused on programs
like the national agricultural imagery program and the current Landsat for your recovery study nape is run by USDA and
it takes aerial imagery of the entire country every couple of years they are considering reducing the collection
frequency or putting it under a proprietary license and Landsat this is
actually as some of the people investigators worked in realize the third time they've tried to privatize this uh-huh and it hasn't really worked

run and they want to try to recover whatever costs they can to make sure they keep the lights on some of the

law of the United States as we make the case for why this data needs to remain open those are really important things

open these datasets because they're revenue streams that the postal service counts on or they're datasets that the

limited levers to get them to share or improve data quality on so yeah I would
say open did the open data act absolutely important and essential for
us to continue making the case and preserving the resources as as they exist I think that the the future of

Jamie I'd like you to close us out before we go to audience questions with you know you've been a champion of open

seen as lessons learned I know what lessons do you know as Canada learned from US efforts the open government data
act individual agencies like HHS order your international colleagues saying is
you know lessons learned what we need to be doing in the future to enable this open open data future the first one is
really an actus not enough the u.s. is far from the only country that is
legislated this stuff you have to do more than just legislate so culture systems that sort of thing the value
proposition is not systematically embraced I think and then there's a role for emerging tech and I'll touch on each really briefly so in terms of
mainstreaming we've had mandatory policy instruments in place for a number of years now
many countries I'm thinking government of France for example with its law for Digital Republic a lot of countries have
legislated this stuff it's not enough to just slap a law on something and hope for the best right so you have to create
systems and culture to enable a real mainstreaming of this work and I'll give you a couple of examples of ways that
we've done that in Canada one of the things that we required under our directive on open government was the creation of data inventories and it was
really really positive we did it because we wanted to say okay what's the universe of Government of Canada data
holdings and on the basis of that prioritized the release of high quality content clean it up get it out sort of
thing what we found was that there was actually very poor information management to start with so open data
sort of the excuse of open data obliged us to get ourselves organized in terms of our data assets and then once we
created those inventories we were able to then work with the departments and agencies in the federal family to push this agenda forward it was also really

first time that they did this data inventory exercise we said well we don't actually need to see the data we just

what that percentage was that was too sensitive to be named it was 8% okay so

I go out and talk to to government entities all the time and I say well you know the the fact that trucks are
